source.39a39299:
Requirement Description Points Earned
Originality All code is your own. Any code snippets that are not your own are properly cited. No more than 5 lines from any website. 10 points
Planning & Reflection The "make a plan" section includes a detailed description of how you plan to complete the project. Reflection is thoughtful and answers all required questions. 10 points 10
Compiles Code Compiles 10 points 10
Comments Code is properly commented 10 points 10
Conventions Naming and style conventions are approriate 10 points 9
More Planning Your planning includes a decision tree and pesudocode 10 points 0
Results There are at least 5 unique results. 10 points 10
Options At least 2 questions have more than two choices 10 points 10
No Nonsense The end result is based on answers to previous questions and makes sense. 10 points 10
if, elif, else if, elif, and else are all used when approriate 10 points 2
--- "Final" Score: 81 / 100 * Did you make a decision tree? Make sure you do that! If you do it on paper, turn it in to me! * Good! Make sure if multiple ifs go together, you have an elif. Also, you should always have an else statement. * Why have me pick a number? Why not just have me type mountain? * When you have a word and a number, you don't need an underscore. ex ```answer1``` instead of ```answer_1``` ---
source.b26906b6:
Here, write a 1 paragraph reflection answering the following questions:

*   What was the hardest part of this project?
*   What was the easiesy part of this project?
*   How did you utilize your peer feedback?
* What was different between your plan and the final project?
* How well did you plan? Was your idea too easy? Too hard? Just right?
* If you had unlimited time, what would you add to this project?
source.7039f998: The hardest part of this project was Kaggle either not running or transforming my code blocks into markdown blocks. The eisiest was creating the inputs and the idea. I added some more else/ elif statements. My plan was pretty similar to my final project just a lot shorter. My idea was pretty easy maybe a little too easy. I added some "or" statements to add a little something more to the project.
source.43a9b826: I plan on making a map quiz that will tell you where to go based on user input to questions.
source.b9d23524:
You will have one of three options for this project. *For both options, make sure your planning includes a decision tree and pseudocode. You may do your decision tree on paper if you would like.* **Planning and commenting your code will help you on this project a LOT** 

For both, you need to have:
* at least 5 unique results
* at least 2 questions with more than 2 choices

**Option 1: Map Quiz**

First, [take a look at this flowchart quiz](https://i.pinimg.com/236x/65/a8/88/65a8889a1c1f2ff796eeb6920277d902.jpg). You will be making a quiz similar to this. You may choose your topic. It might look something like this:

```
I will tell you where to go on vacation!

What kind of weather do you like? (warm, cold, neutral)
warm

What language do you want to speak on vacation? (English, Spanish, French)
English

Can you afford a flight overseas? (yes, no)
no

You are going on vacation to Richmond, Virginia!
```


**Option 2: Choose your own adventure**

You may have to google "choose your own adventure" to see how it works, or check with your peers around you. It might look something like this:
```
There are three doors in front of you, which do you go through? (type door 1, door 2, or door 3)
door 1

Behind door 1 is a lion. What do you do? (fight it, run away, accept death)
fight it

You fought it and survived! You lost a leg though.
```


**Want to make it better?**
* add questions, options, or results
* make it so that a user can enter multiple versions ("yes" and "Yes" both work)
* add a mini game to it!
* anything else!
